column5: R. Resnick, D. Halliday, K. Krane
column6: John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

column5: D. Halliday, R. Resnick, K. Krane
column6: John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
Historically defined as one ten-millionth of the distance between the North Pole and Paris, the modern meter is the length traveled by a light wave in vacuum in 1/299,792,458 seconds.

Historically, a kilogram was defined as the mass of one cubic liter of water. The mass of a kilogram today is defined as the mass of a platinum-iridium cylinder internationally agreed-upon to be one kilogram.
The second is defined as the duration of 9,192,631,770 vibrations of radiation of a certain cesium atom. On a less formal level, we think of a second as 1/60th of a minute, 1/3600 of an hour, etc.
A mole is defined as 6.02214199 * 10^23 atoms. This is known as Avogadro's number.

One Kelvin is defined as 1/273.16 the temperature of the triple point of water, at which solid, liquid, and gaseous water coexist in happy equilibrium. This is equivalent to 0 degrees Celsius or 32 degrees Fahrenheit. A particle at 0K has zero thermal motion, an unattainable state.

Today we define a temperature ($T_c$) on the Celsius scale in terms of the corresponding Kelvin temperature T, by $T_c$=$T$ - 273.15. The freezing and boiling points of water (at a pressure of 1 atm) are now measured on the Kelvin scale and then converted to Celsius using this equation. The values are respectively 0.00 degrees C and 99.975 degrees C .
The SI unit of current is the ampere (A)

The joule, symbol J, is a derived unit of energy, work, or amount of heat. It is equal to the energy expended (or work done) in applying a force of one newton through a distance of one metre (1 newton meter or N·m), or in passing an electric current of one ampere through a resistance of one ohm for one second.
A Newton is a unit of force.
The Coulomb is a unit of electrical charge, equal to one Ampere second.
Volts are a measure of electric potential difference, or eletric potential energy difference per unit test charge. $V = \frac{U}{q_0}$
In physics, and electronics, the henry (symbol H) is the SI derived unit of inductance.
The Ohm is a measure of resistance in an electrical system. $R = \frac{\Delta V}{i} $
A Hertz is a unit of frequency. It is defined as the number of events occurring in one second.

The SI unit of pressure is the Pascal (Pa; 1Pa = $ \frac{ N }{ m^2 } $). Pressure has dimensions of force divided by area and a wide variety of other units can be found. In the United States tire pressure gauges are often in $ \frac{lb}{in^2 }$. The standard pressure exerted  by the atmosphere of the Earth at sea level is designated as 1 atmosphere (atm; 1 atm = 14.7 $ \frac{ lb }{ in^2 } $ = 1.01325 x $10^5$ Pa).
The Tesla is a measure of magnetic field strength.
The radian is a unit of angle. An angle of one radian is subtended when its arc length is equal in measure to its radius.
The Farad is a measure of capacitance, or amount of energy able to be stored in an electric field by a capacitor.

Any Influence that causes an object to undergo a certain change, either concerning its movement, direction, or geometrcial construction. A force can cause an object with mass to change velocity, deform, or both. Force can intuitively be thought of as a push or a pull. A force has both a magnitude and a direction making it a vectore quantity.

Mass is an intrinsic property of matter. If something exists and occupies a volume, it has mass. Unlike weight, mass is independent of gravity. If you weighed yourself on Earth and again on the Moon, you would notice a large decrease in your weight, because the Moon has a much weaker gravitational pull, but your mass would remain unchanged.

Position is a measure of distance. It is defined as the displacement between an object and the origin, which you're usually allowed to place wherever you want. Displacement is a vector, which means it must have an associated direction.
The speed of light in vaccum is a universal constant which is 2.998 x 10^8 and is the speed at which all electromagnetic radiation travels in vaccum

The Gravitational constant, approximately 6.67 x 10^(-11) N(m/kg)^2, is an empirical physical constant used in calculating the gravitational force between two bodies. This is not to be confused with g, the free-fall acceleration on Earth, which is not universal.
Avogadro's constant is the number of particles in one mole of a given substance. This value is 6.022 x 10^23 1/mol

The physical constant $\epsilon_0$, commonly called the vacuum permittivity, permittivity of free space or electric constant, is an ideal, (baseline) physical constant, which is the value of the absolute (not relative) dielectric permittivity of classical vacuum. Its value is: 8.85 x 10^(-12) F/m (Farads per meter).

The physical constant $\mu_0$, commonly called the vacuum permeability, permeability of free space, or magnetic constant is an ideal, (baseline) physical constant, which is the value of magnetic permeability in a classical vacuum. Vacuum permeability is derived from production of a magnetic field by an electric current or by a moving electric charge and in all other formulas for magnetic-field production in a vacuum. µ0 = 4π×10^(−7) V·s/(A·m) ≈ 1.2566370614...×10^(−6) H/m or N·A^(−2) or T·m/A or Wb/(A·m)

The Boltzmann constant (k or kB) is a physical constant relating energy at the individual particle level with temperature. It is the gas constant R divided by the Avogadro number. This constant is commonly used in the formula PV=NkT (where P is pressure, V is volume, N is number of particles, k is the Boltzman Constant, and T is temperature). The value of k is 1.3806488(13)×10^(−23) J/K = 8.6173324(78)×10^(−5) eV/K
The elementary charge is equal to the electrical charge of a proton or neutron: 1.6 * 10^-19 C
The electron mass is approximately 9.109 382 91 × 10^(−31) kg
The proton mass is approximately 1.672621777×10^(−27) kg
The rate at which the velocity of an object is changing with respect to time

Torque, moment or moment of force, is the tendency of a force to rotate an object about an axis, fulcrum, or pivot. Just as a force is a push or a pull, a torque can be thought of as a twist to an object.

A vector quantity, linear momentum is defined as the product of an object's mass and velocity. Momentum is conserved in elastic collisions, where objects bounce off each other, but not in inelastic collisions, where they stick together.

In classical mechanics, the impulse of force (noted as J or Imp) is defined as the product of the average force multiplied by the time it is exerted. Impulse is a vector quantity since force is a vector quantity. The SI unit of impulse is the newton second (N·s) or, in base units, the kilogram meter per second (kg·m/s). Impulse is also defined as the change in the linear momentum of a body.

A force is said to do work when it acts on a body, and there is a displacement of the point of application in the direction of the force. The SI unit of work is the joule (J), which is defined as the work expended by a force of one newton through a distance of one meter (N*m).
Pi ($\pi$) is a mathematical constant that represents the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter: approximately equal to 3.14159.

The coefficient of friction is the ratio of the frictional force between two objects and the normal force exerted by one upon the other. It is an intrinsic property of a given material. There are two types of frictional coefficients: static and kinetic. The coefficient of static friction applies to an object at rest, while the kinetic applies to one in motion. Generally, the coefficient of static friction is larger than the coefficient of kinetic friction. Ice has a low coefficient, while asphalt has a comparatively high one.

The kinetic energy of an object is the energy which is possesses due to its motion. In classical mechanics, the kinetic energy of a non-rotating object of mass m traveling at a speed v is ½ mv². The SI unit for measuring work and energy is the joule (symbol J). In relativistic mechanics, this is only a good approximation when v is much less than the speed of light.
The net work done by the forces acting on a body is equal to the change in the body's kinetic energy.
The period of a cyclic event is the time it takes for the system to complete one full revolution and return to its starting point. It is the inverse of frequency.

The frequency of a cyclic event is the number of revolutions of the system in a given timeframe. It is the inverse of the period. The Hertz unit uses seconds for this time frame. Something with a frequency of 60 Hz occurs sixty times per second. Frequency is sometimes represented by the Greek letter nu.

Friction is the force of resistance to motion offered by a surface. Its direction is always opposite to that of the motion of the contact surface. The frictional force offered by a material is dependent on its intrinsic coefficient of friction (given by the Greek letter mu). Ice has a very low coefficient, while a rough wooden floor has a comparatively high one.

The centripetal force is not a new kind of force. When a particle moves in a circular path at constant speed, several forces may act upon it. The resultant of those forces must point toward the center of the circle, and we call the resultant of these forces the centripetal force.

Two equal and opposite charges separated by a distance are known as an $electric dipole$. In equations in electricity and magnetism, we often find the product of their charge and distance $qd$, and thus we find it convenient to store this information into a variable known as the $electric dipole moment \textbf{ vec{p} }$. The direction of the moment points from the negative charge to the positive by convention.

Coulomb's constant is a handy way of containing the fraction: $\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}$, which comes up often in equations in electricity and magnetism. It has the numerical value: $ K = 8.99 \times 10^9 \frac{ \textrm{N} \cdot \textrm{m}^2}{ \textrm{C}^2 } $.
An angle is formed by two rays emanating from the same point, the $vertex$. It can be measured in degrees or radians.
Time is the order in which events occur, measured in seconds.
Velocity is the time-rate change in position. It can intuitively be thought of as speed with a given direction.
The normal force is the force exerted on an object by a surface. It is a consequence of Newton's Third Law.
The radius of a circle is the distance between its center and an endpoint. It is often used in place of distance, as in calculation of the gravitational force.
Acceleration due to gravity is felt by an object falling freely near a massive object, such as the Earth. It is the acceleration that an apple experiences as it falls from a tree.

Electrical charge is induced by the transfer of valence electrons from one object to another. By convention, a positively-charged object ($+$) has a deficiency in electrons, while a negatively-charged one ($-$) has a surplus. Because the quantity of charge is related to the number of valence electrons, we say that it is $quantized$, or that it only comes in integer multiples of the elementary charge.

The centripetal force is not a new kind of force. When a particle moves in a circular path at constant speed, several forces may act upon it. The resultant of those forces must point toward the center of the circle, and we call the resultant of these forces the centripetal force.
The electric field acts as an intermediary through which the electric force can act. Charged objects moving through an electric field will experience a force proportional to the charge.
The electric force is a force of attraction or repulsion between two charged objects whose direction is dependent on the polarity of each object. It is described by Coulomb's Law.

Gravitational potential energy in a system is dependent on how far away one massive object is from another. In systems where the Earth is one of those objects, it is dependent on the distance above the ground (or some other defined zero-point, i.e., a tabletop). It can be thought of as representing the kinetic energy the object $would$ gain before hitting the ground if it were allowed to fall freely to the surface.
The force exerted by one massive object on another is described by Newton's Law of Gravitation.

The potential energy $U$ is energy associated with the configuration of a system: how the parts of the system are located or arranged with respect to one another (for example, the compression of a spring in a box-spring system, or the height of a ball in the ball-Earth system). The SI units of potential energy are Joules (J).
The period of a pendulum describes how long, in seconds, it takes for the bob to make one full cycle and return back to its starting position.

The spring constant is an intrinsic property of a spring that denotes how resistant to stretching or compressing it is. A spring with a constant of 10 N/m is twice as difficult to stretch or compress as one with a constant of 5 N/m.
The period of a spring defines how long, in seconds, it takes for the spring to go from stretched to compressed and back again when acted upon by some outside force.
The spring force is defined by Hooke's Law. It is the force that must be exerted on a spring to stretch or compress it some distance x, and the force with which the spring would recoil once released.
Potential energy is stored in a spring when it is stretched or compressed away from equilibrium. It is dependent on the distance the spring is moved and the spring constant.

Here $F$ is the magnitude of the mutual force that acts on each of the two charges $q_1$ and $q_2$ and $r$ is the distance between their centers. As required by Newton's third law, the force exerted by $q_1$ on $q_2$ is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to the force exerted by $q_2$ on $q_1$, even though the magnitudes of the charges may be different.

column5: Velocity over Time with Constant Acceleration
column6: The velocity of an object is equal to the original velocity, with respect to some initial time, plus the acceleration of the object multiplied by the final time minus the initial time.

Newton's Second Law states that the vector sum of the forces on an object is equal to the total mass of that object multiplied by the acceleration of the object. In more technical terms, the acceleration of a body is directly proportional to, and in the same direction as, the net force acting on the body, and inversely proportional to its mass. Thus, F = ma, where F is the net force acting on the object, m is the mass of the object and a is the acceleration of the object. Force and acceleration are both vectors. This means that they have both a magnitude (size) and a direction relative to some reference frame.

This is a kinematics equation which describes the motion of points, bodies (objects) and systems of bodies (groups of objects) without consideration of the causes of motion. Newton's laws state that a constant force acting on a particle generates a constant acceleration. This is called projectile motion.

column5: Velocity at a Position with Constant Acceleration
column6: This is a kinematics equation which describes the motion of points, bodies (objects) and systems of bodies (groups of objects) without consideration of the causes of motion. Newton's laws state that a constant force acting on a particle generates a constant acceleration. This is called projectile motion.

Friction is the force resisting the motion of solid surfaces, fluid layers, and material elements sliding against each other. There are several types of friction such as dry friction, fluid friction, and sliding friction. The equation shown here represents a case of dry friction.
A body moving in a circle of radius R at velocity v experiences a centripetal acceleration in the radial direction.

Torque, moment or moment of force, is the tendency of a force to rotate an object about an axis, fulcrum, or pivot. Just as a force is a push or a pull, a torque can be thought of as a twist to an object. Torque can also be thought of as T= r x F

In classical mechanics, linear momentum or translational momentum (SI unit kg m/s, or equivalently, N s) is the product of the mass and velocity of an object. Momentum is also a conserved quantity meaning that if a closed system is not affected by external forces, its total linear momentum cannot change.
Like velocity, linear momentum is a vector quantity, possessing a direction as well as a magnitude

In classical mechanics, impulse (symbolized by J) is the change in linear momentum of a body. It may be defined or calculated as the product of the average force multiplied by the time over which the force is exerted. Impulse is a vector quantity since it is the result of integrating force, a vector quantity, over time. The SI unit of impulse is the newton second (N·s) or, in base units, the kilogram meter per second (kg·m/s).

The kinetic energy of an object is the energy which is possesses due to its motion. In classical mechanics, the kinetic energy of a non-rotating object of mass m traveling at a speed v is ½ mv². The SI unit for measuring work and energy is the joule (symbol J). In relativistic mechanics, this is only a good approximation when v is much less than the speed of light.

Potential energy is energy stored in a system of forcefully interacting physical entities. The SI unit for measuring work and energy is the joule (symbol J). Potential energy is often associated with restoring forces such as a spring or the force of gravity. The action of stretching the spring or lifting the mass is performed by an external force that works against the force field of the potential.

In physics the concept of work involves a force that is exerted as the point of application moves through some distance, and one way to define the energy of a system is a measure of its capacity to do work. The SI unit of work is the joule (J), which is defined as the work expended by a force of one newton through a distance of one meter.
Hooke's law is a principle of physics that states that the force F needed to extend or compress a spring by some distance X is proportional to that distance.
This equation represents the potential energy of an "ideal" spring of force constant k, compressed or extended by a distance "x" from its rest position.
The period of a spring in motion is the time in seconds it takes for the end of the spring to complete one full compression-extension cycle.
The period of a pendulum is the time in seconds it takes for the bob to complete one full cycle.
$T$ is the period in seconds (s), meaning the number of seconds per cycle. $T$ is the reciprocal of frequency.

The potential energy $U$ is energy associated with the configuration of a system. This means how the parts of the system are located or arranged with respect to one another (for example, the compression of a spring in a box-spring system, or the height of a ball in the ball-Earth system). The SI units of potential energy are Joules (J).

Gravitation is the force that acts between bodies due to only their masses and is one of the four basic forces of physics. The negative sign is traditionally used to denote that it is an attracive force.

The potential energy is a property of a system of two particles $m_1$ and $m_2$, rather than of either body alone. The potential energy changes whether $m_1$ or $m_2$ is displaced. Each is acted upon by the gravitational force of the other.

Here $F$ is the magnitude of the mutual force that acts on each of the two charges $q_1$ and $q_2$ and $r$ is the distance between their centers. As required by Newton's third law, the force exerted by $q_1$ on $q_2$ is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to the force exerted by $q_2$ on $q_1$, even though the magnitudes of the charges may be different.

Dimensionally, the electric field is the force per unit charge, and its SI unit is the newton/coulomb (N/C) although it is also often given in the unit of volt/meter (V/m). Note the similarity with the gravitational field. Both the gravitational and electric fields can be expressed as a force divided by a property (mass or charge) of the test body.

The normal force is the counteracting force of a surface on an object. For example, as a book rests on a table, gravity exerts a downward force on the table proprortional to the mass of the book. In accord with Newton's Third Law, because the book does not fall through the table, there must then be a force equal in magnitude in the opposite direction of the gravitational force. This is "normal", or perpendicular, to the surface, hence the name "normal force".

The centripetal force is not a new kind of force. When a particle moves in a circular path at constant speed, several forces may act upon it. The resultant of those forces must point toward the center of the circle, and we call the resultant of these forces the centripetal force.

The center of mass of an object or system is the point at which the mass on each side of it is balanced. For example, a barbell with equal weight on each side would have a center of mass exactly at the center, but adding weight to one side would move the center of mass in that direction. The center of mass of many-body systems can be calculated in this way as well.
The net work done by the forces acting on a body is equal to the change in kinetic energy of the body

The configuration of two equal and opposite charges separated by a distance is called an electric dipole. The magnitude  of the charge q on each of the components and their separation d often occur together as the product qd. It is convient to dfine this quantity as the electric dipole moment p.

Electric charge is the physical property of matter that causes it to experience a force when close to other electrically charged matter. There are two types of electric charges: positive (+) and negative (-). Positively charged substances are repelled from other positively charged substances, but attracted to negatively charged substances. Negatively charged substances are repelled from negative and attracted to positive. An object will be negatively charged if it has an excess of electrons, and will otherwise be positively charged or uncharged. The SI derived unit of electric charge is the coulomb (C), although in electrical engineering it is also common to use the ampere-hour (Ah), and in chemistry it is common to use the elementary charge (e) times an integer ($n = 0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots$) as a unit. The symbol Q is often used to denote a charge.
